g.text: XPS spectra corresponding to the final stage of Cs-K-Sb growth are presented. Spectra from survey meas-
urements of P006 and P007 (top panel) show the elemental composition of the photocathode materials. Peaks
associated to specific core states are clearly visible, with those referring to Cs 3
the most prominent and identifiable features in the spectrum. The stoichiometry of the samples Â is determined
from the relative peak intensities of the aforementioned peaks, as reported in TableÂ
such as the one shown forÂ K 2
(see inset of the top panelÂ in Fig.Â
) offer additional insight in determining peak
positions and shifts, and are also useful for peak fittings. The K 2
peak positions in the spectra ofÂ P006 and P007
are very similar. The sizable shifts predicted by theory are actually not observed in the top panel of Fig.Â
not surprising, considering that photocathode samples are non-stoichiometric (see Fig.Â
amorphous or polycrystalline regions with different stoichiometry.
Real photocathodes are also subject to the possibility of oxygen contamination due to residual gases of K and
Cs dispensers. A detailed region spectrum of the Sb 3
regions for P007 is shown in the bottom panel
. The oxygen contamination of a sample can be calculated from this plot by extracting the relative peak
states. Since the binding energies shown in the plot in Fig.Â
so close, the spectrum has been deconvoluted to identify the individual contributions of the O 1
(blue and orange dashed lines) and Sb
dashed lines). For reference, the raw measured data is reported with offset (black solid line) together with the
Shirley background (black dashed line), which has been subtracted to obtain the deconvoluted spectrum in the
foreground. From this graph it is clear that the P007 sample is dominated byÂ antimony atoms with Sb
state. Very minor contributions from Sb
can be seen only for the 3
electron at 527.6 eV. For P007 we also see
some oxygen contamination identified by the broad peak centred at 532.6 eV, which is visible also in the stoichi-
is exemplary to the characterization of a pho-
tocathode sample which highlights the chemical nature of the grown material, which contain oxygen impurities
and non-stoichoimetric composition, as discussed below with reference to Fig.Â
the correlation between QE, measured under illumination with 532 nm wavelength, and stoichiomet-
ric content of Cs and K atoms is presented for a selected number of Cs-K-Sb samples grown at HZB (for details,
see the Experimental Setup below). The relative oxygen contamination (ratio of O 1
each sample is indicated according to the colour scale on the right-hand side of the figure: Green points corre-
spond to oxygen-free cathodes, while red dots are referred to samples with up to 0.2 relative oxygen content. For
pristine single crystals, such as those modelled by DFT, corresponding to CsK
would expect to see two distinct clusters of samples around
Cs content. In reality, the grown samples are polycrystalline in nature, thus composed of grains of the two differ-
ent stoichiometries. The presence of other crystal phases rather than the most stable cubic ones considered in the
DFT calculations cannot be excluded. The stoichiometric content of the samples presented in Fig.Â
value averaged over a surface of several mm
. As a result, the points on both panels in Fig.Â
and also expanding above and below it. We notice a correla-
tion between the amount of oxygen content and the QE, in particular in theÂ samples P014 and P015, which
exhibit highest purity and, concomitantly, highest efficiency among the data points reported in Fig.Â
other hand, the relatively large QE of P013 and, conversely, the relatively low QE of P011, do not allow us to draw
general conclusions. Overall, in the presented pool of samples, those with stoichiometry close to the Cs
exhibit the highest QE. We finally remark that while from Fig.Â
one may evince that no K content leads to a max-
imized QE, for the operation of the cathodes in the bERLinPro accelerator, specific constraints in term of material
robustness and thermal stability have to be fulfilled. Such criteria are met by Cs-K-Sb compounds but not entirely
We conclude this section by benchmarking the spin-orbit splitting, which is clearly visible in the calculated
values of core binding energies in TableÂ
, as well as in the measured XPS spectra (see Fig.Â
references. In this way, we can use spin-orbit splitting, which is known to be an atomic property, as a parameter
to validate both computed and measured values. We summarize this comparison in TableÂ
the results of spin-orbit splitting for three selected states (Cs 3
Sb calculated compounds) with those reported in ref.
for the corresponding elemental crystals. The
comparison with DFT values reveals a very good agreement for K 2
5%. The computed spin-orbit splitting for Cs 3
is instead overestimated by DFT by slightly more than 10%.
Analogous trends are obtained also for the experimental values, where the discrepancy between Cs
Sb can be attributed to the uncertainty of the measurement. In this case, the splittings of K 2
smaller than the reference. It should also be noticed that the experimental data reported in TableÂ
from samples P007 and P015, which are not perfectly stoichiometric (see Fig.Â
are not meaningful to identify different stoichiometries, the mutual agreement between DFT and XPS results, also
